column4: how can I create a new alias for a script and have it receive the additinal parameters?
i want to create an alias for php...
when I run php, I woudl have php -c /path/to/new/php.ini
edit your ~/.bashrc and add: alias php="php -c ...."
prper use of quotes is important, alias php="php -c /home/group8/shortcuts "
the alias is just a shell shothand notation; it only applies to things run directly from the shell
another trick would be to create a small shell script called "php" and set the $PATH variable so it finds your script before the real php
make sure that when you run php from the script that you type the full path so you don't end up executing the script over and over
the first directory in PATH has preference
told you to use the full path so you didn't execute your script repeatedly
your script is called php, your script then runs php, which according to $PATH is the same script ...
keep in mind that when an executable file has a header like "#!/usr/bin/php" that's actually a command to execute /usr/bin/php
that's what I'm tryign to overcome right nwo
so it does have that header?

ok, that is known as an interpreter; it tells the kernel how to execute the file, which in this case means "run /ur/bin/php and give it the filename" .. since you can't change the header, the only thing you can do is eecute php yourself and pass it in the filename of the executable
(or make your own copy of the script with a different header)
